text:
Cheers for the response - I don't have 10k results for most of my examples, although they are actually fairly basic (a double-edged sword in terms of trying to assert significance - are they basic and so easy to test and assert, or basic and there is a mistake in the process). They do turn up in places that I conceptualised as having inefficient markets; but is it confirmation bias? What do you think is longshot bias? At 10,000 you've seen each 100:1 100 times, which I would guesstimate as necessary. If my average odds price is 10, I think 1000 should be acceptable?

I have no idea whatsoever, so not asserting anything just proposing and seeing what you guys think

text:
Id echo river_shar comments here. The more the better I think. Here is a real example from 2021. Around 5K markets 21k bets (and isnt dependant on weak long shot signals, so you may have expected he graph to be smoother). The first 2.5K markets gives a very different view from the second half results.

edit: This was inplay

text: If you are betting pre-event and can assess the EV of your bets using BSP rather than relying on realised return then this will dramatically reduce the required sample size to draw conclusions

elements.text: If you are betting pre-event and can assess the EV of your bets using BSP rather than relying on realised return then this will dramatically reduce the required sample size to draw conclusions

text: As has been said it depends on what you're doing exactly, but I'd normally set the bar lower than <@U01B8031PM1>. There are about 6k flat races in the UK and Ireland each year and and the same number of jumps races so you could set that as a reasonable number.
